How we built an MCP Agent from scratch

No magic. No fluff. Just an MCP Agent that actually works.

It‚Äôs 2025, and sure, we‚Äôve got CrewAI, n8n, and a dozen other shiny tools.

But sometimes, you just want to get your hands dirty and build something real, start to finish.

So that‚Äôs the vibe: a bit nostalgic, a bit stubborn ‚Ä¶ and 100% builder mindset.

In this article, I‚Äôll show you how

Alex Razvant
and I did exactly that with our Kubrick Agent ‚Äî a fully functional agent, built from scratch, that talks directly to our Video Processing MCP Server (if you‚Äôve been following along, you know the one).

How real AI Engineers build MCP Servers

No shortcuts friend. Let‚Äôs get into it üëá

The Kubrick Agent

I know that diagram might look a little scary at first, but don‚Äôt sweat it ‚Äî we‚Äôre going to break it all down step by step, starting today and wrapping it up next week.

üí° Today‚Äôs spotlight: the Agent implementation!

So, what makes up our Agent (or MCP Agent, if we‚Äôre being fancy)?

It‚Äôs got four key parts:

  1. Core agent logic - This is the brains of the operation. We‚Äôre defining how it routes tasks, uses tools, and does its thing (all from scratch). No agentic workflows here, just Groq API calls!

  2. Memory layer - Agents need to remember stuff, right? For short-term memory, we‚Äôre using Pixeltable to keep things persistent.

  3. MCP Client + MCP Tool management - We cooked up an MCP client so our agent can connect to the tools and prompts living in the MCP Server.

  4. Agent tracing - A peek behind the scenes to see what the agent‚Äôs up to. We‚Äôll cover this bit next week!

Alright, let‚Äôs see how the core logic works.

Agent Core Logic

When it comes to the core agent logic, there are two classes in the source code you‚Äôll want to pay extra attention to: BaseAgent and GroqAgent.

GroqAgent is just a subclass of BaseAgent, but it‚Äôs where things get interesting. Here‚Äôs a quick look at the chat method inside GroqAgent:

This method takes in the user‚Äôs message, plus a video_path and image_base64 if those are provided. From there, it runs through four major steps:

  1. Routing: First, it figures out if any tools are needed to answer the user‚Äôs query.

  2. Tool use: If tools are needed, it calls _run_with_tool ‚Äî this is where the agent decides which tool to use from the MCP Server.

  3. Simple response: If no tools are needed, it calls _respond_general to generate a straightforward answer instead.

  4. Memory storage: Finally, it saves both the user‚Äôs query and the assistant‚Äôs response in a Pixeltable table.

More on that last step in the next section üëá

Pixeltable Memory Layer

Alright, let‚Äôs talk about that memory piece.

Once the Agent generates a response ‚Äî whether it uses a tool or not ‚Äî it needs to store what just happened. That‚Äôs where the Pixeltable Memory Layer comes in.

In our case, we‚Äôre using Pixeltable to persist (just) the short-term memory. Every user query and the Agent‚Äôs response get logged into a Pixeltable table.

üí° This makes it easy to look back at interactions, debug issues, or just keep the context for future chats.

It‚Äôs simple but super handy. It also sets the stage for more advanced memory strategies down the line if we need them.

MCP Client + MCP Tool management

Just like Cursor or Claude Desktop, our Kubrick Agent needs an MCP Client to hook into the Video Processing MCP Server.

Thanks to FastMCP, this is embarrassingly easy.

Seriously, take a peek at the code for the BaseAgent and you‚Äôll see how straightforward it is create an MCP Client using this library:

Apart from the MCP Client, we also need a Tool discovery method. This handles fetching all the tools from the MCP Server and translating them into the format that Groq expects.

If you‚Äôre curious about how that works under the hood, check out the GroqTool class ‚Äî it‚Äôs responsible for this transformation logic and makes sure the tools are ready to roll when the Agent needs them.

With the tool discovery and this tool translation logic in place, the Groq Agent would never suspect it‚Äôs actually getting its tools from a remote MCP Server! üòâ

It all just works seamlessly behind the scenes.

üìå This article is just a quick intro to everything you‚Äôll find in the Kubrick repo. I encourage you to dive in ‚Äî try configuring it yourself, tweak it, improve it, or even break it!

That‚Äôs the best way to really learn how it all works.

Feels so good after a solid session of building from scratch!

Better than yoga. Way better than CrossFit.

Just a good cup of coffee and a multimodal agent, built from the ground up.
